Tiene muchas aspiración es en continuar con su trabajo pero por ahora quiere mejorar el estilo de vida de su familia por eso quiere comprar con el préstamo cemento, arena, bloques para construir mejor su casa.
texts.en:
Federico is a hard-working man who took on the responsibility of supporting his family from a young age.  He started working for a club called 'Sport Emelec' (one of Ecuador's well-known soccer clubs) as a bus driver. 

Federico has kept going in his job in order to support his family.  He works from very early in the morning, transporting and collecting the soccer players.  He has many aspirations to continue in his job but, for now, he would like to improve his family's lifestyle.  He would like to use his loan to buy cement, sand and blocks to better build his home.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand and blocks

loans.name: Agustina Monserrate

texts.es:
En una localidad llamada Tierras Amarillas del cantón Rocafuerte cada quince días  se reúnen las socias del Banco Comunal Mejorando El Futuro, este sector es conocido por su agricultura ya que gran parte de sus habitantes se dedican a los sembríos de ciclo corto.

La señora Agustina es socia fundadora del Banco comunal y le gusta porque le han ayudado mucho los créditos tanto  a ella como a sus amigas del banco. Tiene  57 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene tres hijos los cuales ya son mayores de edad e independientes. Su esposo es comerciante.

Ella es una gran ama de casa que realiza el crédito para el negocio de su esposo, él vende productos del mar, su marido se desplaza todos los días hasta el mercado de Portoviejo para comprar variedad de mariscos para sus clientes,  se abastece de camarón, calamar, pescado, conchas, cangrejo, etc.  Y  luego en su triciclo sale a recorrer con  sus productos.

Este crédito es para comprar calamares, camarón, pescado, cangrejos, entre otras especies de mariscos.  Está en el Banco Comunal hace 6 años y le gusta por el apoyo y ayuda que ha recibido.  Su sueño es arreglar su casa ya que está viejita.
texts.en:
The members of the “Mejorando El Futuro” (Improving the Future) communal bank meet every other week in an area called Tierras Amarillas in the Rocafuerte canton.  This sector is known for its agriculture because most of its inhabitants grow short cycle crops.

Agustina is a founding member of the communal bank.  She likes it because the loans have helped her and her friends in the bank a lot.  She is 57 years old, married, and has three children.  The children are grown and independent.  Her husband is a merchant.

She is a great housewife who wants the loan for her husband’s business.  He sells products from the sea.  Every day he goes to the market in Portoviejo to buy a variety of seafood for his customers.  He stocks up on shrimp, squid, fish, scallops, and crab, etc.  He then leaves in his tricycle to travel around with his products.

This loan is to buy squid, shrimp, fish, and crabs, among other types of seafood.  She has been in the communal bank for six years.  She likes it because of the help and support she has received.

Her dream is to fix up her house because it is a bit old.

loans.use: to buy fish, squid, shrimp, and crabs, etc.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth N. is from the village of Maranding, Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 34 years old. Ruth is widowed and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Ruth owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling variety of dried fish like bolinao & tamban in the local community. Ruth has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Ruth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruth is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stocks of dried fish to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Ruth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of dried fish to sell

loans.name: Gladys Del Pilar

texts.es:
Gladys tiene 33 años D. edad, es casada y resiD. junto a su esposos y sus tres hijos en el caserío Santa Elena que está a 15 km del distrito agrícola D. TambogranD., una zona agrícola situada en la región Piura, a más D. cuatro horas D. la ciudad D. Chiclayo, capital D. la región Lambayeque.

Ella tiene una bodega instalada en su domicilio. Allí ofrece en venta a sus vecinos diversos productos D. consumo diario entre productos D. primera necesidad y abarrotes. El negocio cuenta con una antigüedad D. 3 años y actualmente cuenta con una clientela fija y fidelizada. Gracias a esta actividad ella ha podido ayudar a su esposo a  solventar los gastos económicos D. su familia.

Gladys desea ampliar su negocio con la compra D. más mercadería, especialmente D. útiles escolares D. modo que pueda satisfacer la demanda D. sus clientes durante la campaña escolar. Por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito D. 2000 nuevos soles.
texts.en:
Gladys is 33 years old, married, and lives with her husband and three children in the village of Santa Elena.  Her village is 15 kilometers from the agricultural district of TambogranD., an agricultural area located in Piura region, more than four hours from the city of Chiclayo, the capital of Lambayeque region.

Gladys has a grocery store located in her home.  She sells a range of essentials and groceries to her neighbors.  She has been in her business for 3 years and has a loyal customer base.  This business has enabled Gladys to help her husband cover their family's financial expenses.

Gladys would like to expand her business by purchasing more merchandise, especially school supplies so that she can meet her customers' demands during this back-to-school season.  For this reason, she is requesting a loan for 2,000 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: to buy merchandise and school supplies for her grocery store

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en: Leonila P. is from the village of Tupsan, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 56 years old. Leonila is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Leonila runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods and beverages. Leonila has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. In 2010, Leonila joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Leonila is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods and snack foods. This will be the third loan taken out by Leonila from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods and snack foods

loans.name: Ramon

texts.en:
Ramon O. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. He is 48 years old. Ramon is separated from his spouse and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Ramon owns & operates a business venture in the food sector operating a mini-restaurant. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from serving a variety of different meals like "escabeche," "adobo", "pancit bihon" & fish soups to customers in the local community. Ramon has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Ramon joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ramon is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Ramon from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant.

loans.name: Felicita Moncerrate

texts.es:
En una localidad llamada Tierras Amarillas del cantón Rocafuerte cada quince días  se reúnen las socias del Banco Comunal Mejorando El Futuro, este sector es conocido por su agricultura ya que gran parte de sus habitantes se dedican a los sembríos de ciclo corto.

Aquí conocimos a la señora Felicita  ella es madre soltera de  un hijo de 20 años de edad el cual es discapacitado, ella vive en casa de sus padres. Lleva en el Banco Comunal cuatro años  y le gusta porque le han ayudado con los créditos los mismos que dan sin tantos requisitos.

Es una madre abnegada que lucha todos los días para que a su hijo no le falte nada, tiene una tienda de víveres de consumo en la casa de sus padres en la cual vende productos como: arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, etc. En ella trabaja todos los días desde las 7h00 hasta las 20h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, los productos compra en el centro de Portoviejo y algunos los  recibe en su local. Nos cuenta que su negocio lo empezó con uno de los créditos que recibió de la Fundación Espoir y esto le permite ganarse la vida honradamente.
 
Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, embutidos y otros productos de primera necesidad. Sus metas son seguir adelante en su negocio.
texts.en:
Every fortnight, the members of the 'Mejorando el Futuro' (Improving the Future) community bank meet in the town of Tierras Amarillas, in Rocafuerte canton.  This area is known for its farming since a large number of its inhabitants work in short-cycle agriculture. 

Here we meet Felicita who is a single mother with a 20 year-old, disabled son.  She lives in her parents' home.  She has been a member of her community bank for four years and enjoys being a member because they have helped her with loans which are offered without many requirements.

Felicita is a selfless mother who works hard every day so that her son doesn't want for anything.  She owns a grocery store, which is located in her parents' home, from which she sells products such as sugar, oil, detergents, etc.  She works in her store every day from 7.00am to 8.00pm and sometimes until even later.  She buys some of her products in Portoviejo and some are delivered to her premises.  She tells us that she started her business with one of her loans from Fundación Espoir and it has allowed her to make an honest living.

Felicita will use this loan to better stock her store.  She will buy rice, sugar, oil, detergents, sausages and other essential products.  Her goal is to continue to make progress in her business.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, oil, detergents, sausages and other essential products

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling vegetables like cabbages, carrots, potatoes, eggplants & "pipino" in the local community. Evangeline has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

Nem M. is 48 years old and married to Chor Nak, 49, a casual construction worker. They live in Reusey Keo commune, in the capital of Phnom Penh. The couple is blessed with five teenage children, two of whom are married and have their own homes, and three of whom still rely on their parents' income. 

Nem M. is a fast food seller in the mobile place by using her motorbike. 

Recently, the family has faced difficulties with living conditions as her house is really old and it needs to be repaired. So she will use this loan to repair her old house.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena L. is from the village of Kidahon, Malinao, Gingoog City. She is 33 years old. Elena is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, instant noodles and detergents in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eleven years and earns approximately $141 a month for these activities.

In 2003, Elena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Elena is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods and snack foods to sell. This will be her 10th loan  from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods and snack foods to sell

loans.name: Meur

texts.en: Mrs. Meur P. is a widow who has been living in a rural area of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. She can make around $3 a profit each day from selling fresh fish at the busy market. She has no a life partner as her husband died of illness for years. Mrs. Meur P. has three children: Two are married and live outside of the family home, while the other one is no longer in school and is employed at the garment factory. She has one son who earns money by driving motorcycle taxi (Tuk Tuk) in and around his community, earning an income on average of $5 per day to share responsibility with Mrs. Meur P. for the family’s expenses. He always picks up the fishes for her before he starts providing his taxi service. Unfortunately, an existing motorbike often has broken down during use. Because of that, Mrs. Meur P. has decided to seek a loan of $1,200 from Kiva, which she will use to change the broken motorcycle for her son.

loans.use: To change the broken motorcycle of her son.

loans.name: Benson

The main source of income for the business comes from fishing and selling seafood products, including fish like sari and kitob, in the local community. In 2010, Benson joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Mary Glenn

texts.en:
Mary Glenn A. is from the village of Layawan, Oroquieta City. She is 48 years old. Mary Glenn is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business of making and selling breads, cakes and cookies to the local community. Mary Glenn has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $238 a month for these activities.

In 2011, Mary Glenn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase flour, sugar, vegetable oil and shortening. This will be her 1st loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Mot

texts.en: Mot R. is a 56-year-old married mother who lives in the best territory of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. Before Mot R. have made a living by selling Khmer cake at home, but now she stays at home to do some duties, the daily activities that she always does such as cooking nice meals, cleaning house, washing clothes, and managing other properties. Her husband is another earner financially; he drives a motorbike taxi. She is married with six children, four of whom are married and have already started new homes. The rest two are single and one of them feeds small fish in the pond behind her house. Mot R. would like to take out her loan for her son to expand his fish-raising business.

loans.use: to assist her son in expanding his fish-raising business

loans.name: Nos

texts.en: Nos R. is 40 years old and a married woman. She was married years ago and has three single children, two of whom work as garment workers in a factory. She and her husband earn a profit by running a business similar to that of a recycled goods seller. They always buy used goods to sell to their wholesaler, who then sells the goods in bulk to other provinces or countries. The used goods the wholesaler deals in are mostly leftover electrical wires and plastic. Nos R. would like to ask for a loan to use as capital to buy more used goods to stock up, to increase her profits.

loans.use: To buy more used goods to stock up for selling

loans.name: Dam

texts.en: Dam K. is a 53-year-old widowed villager who lives in the city of Phnom Penh. She is the mother of four children, two of whom are married. Her husband died of senility years ago. Dam K. has worked as a rice farmer since she was single. She always grows her rice crop on her existing rented farmland. Her family’s living conditions are not so good because their walls are broken due to strong winds. To solve the problem, Dam K. has requested a loan to buy some zinc for building new walls.

loans.use: to buy some zinc for building new walls

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa D. is from the town of District 1, Benito Soliven, Isabela. She is 55 years old. Elsa is married and has nine adult children. 

To make a living, Elsa owns and operates a general store. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Elsa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Elsa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Elsa is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as soft drinks, sugar and coffee. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Elsa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is a 40-year-old married woman who supports her family by selling fish in the market. She lives in Toledo, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard selling fish, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000. Josephine is borrowing PHP 25,000 to purchase stocks of fish to sell in the market.  This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 22,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Josephine aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: to purchase fish

loans.name: Sumber Tanjung Group

texts.en:
Sumber Tanjung Group is located in Singaraja, North Bali. This group has a total membership of 10 people, and all members of the group are women who are married and have children. This group wants to borrow funds in the amount of Rp. 10,000,000. The person who is responsible for the group is Ni Ketut S.. Ni Ketut S. has three children. 

This group has long been managing the business of pigs, and they want to expand their business. For this reason, the members of Sumber Tanjung group chose to take out a loan at MUK to multiply their capital, in order to buy more piglets and also to buy feed for the pigs, so their profit will increase. The result will be additional income for their children's education, and also they can help their husbands in buying the daily necessities in the kitchen.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and also to buy feed for them.

loans.name: Seth

texts.en: Seth S. is 55 and the mother of six children. She is a local farmer who has been planting a variety of crops for years. In addition, she raises a few chickens and piglets in a cage behind her house. She also relies on income from her husband, who is a teacher of English in a village in Siem Reap province and earns around $4 each day. Seth S. is requesting a loan to hire a domestic laborer to harvest her mature rice crops, and buy additional piglets for breeding.

loans.use: to hire a domestic laborer to harvest her mature rice crops, and buy addition piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Huong's Group

texts.en:
Huong T. T. is 32 years old with four children who are attending school. She has a shop that sells construction supplies such as cement, steel, bricks and stone. Her business creates 3,000,000 VND profit per month.  

Having received loans from our credit program in 2007, she used them to buy more material to meet the demand of clients and has always been in a good  repayment situation. 

Currently, she needs a loan of 7,630,000 VND to buy a mini truck for delivery.

Toan V. N. is 35 years old with one child. He  has a small shop that makes windows and doors by using aluminum frames. He wants to borrow 7,194,000 VND to invest in the business.

Quy  T. N. is 27 years old with one child. She is raising seven pigs for meat so she needs to borrow 6,322,000 VND to buy food for them.

loans.use: to buy a mini truck for delivery

loans.name: Hieu

texts.en:
Hieu  T. N. is 43 years old with three children who are at high school.  

Being a farmer, she grows rice and vegetables and raises pigs for meat. Her business is developed and creates a stable income that helps her to cover her living expenses. 

When she received loans from 2007 to 2010, she invested in developing her farming. Based on this, she not only covers all expenses but also has a savings account. 

This year, she wants to have a loan of 8,066,000 VND to improve her house.

loans.use: to improve her house

loans.name: The

texts.en:
The T.  P. is 49 years old with three children.  

Being a farmer, her main activities focus on growing rice and vegetables and raising chickens.  

Since her divorce in 2008, she has had to work more in order to provide a good education for her children. She has increased the number of fields to grow more kinds of vegetables. In this way, she can earn a stable income to manage her family life. 

Participating in our credit program since 2009, she has been a good re-payer and has used loans effectively to develop her farming. 

Currently, she wants to have a loan of 8,066,000 VND to buy food for her chickens and fertilizer for her rice.

loans.use: to buy food for her chickens and fertilizer for her rice

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle for her daughters to commute to work

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Kim T. N. is 26  years old with two children who are at  high school. She is  a very hard working farmer. Currently, she is growing rice, beans and corn in a paddy of 4,200 square meters. Her agricultural  products are used to support her family's food demand and a part of them is sold  to earn daily income. 

Since joining the SEDA credit program in 2007, she has used her loans very effectively and has always been a good re-payer. 

To buy seed and fertilizer for her next crop, she wants to have a loan of 4,142,000,000 VND.

loans.use: to buy  seed and fertilizer for her next crop

loans.name: May

texts.en:
May T. D. was born in 1957. She lives in Ha Lam 3 village with her husband and two children. 

She grows rice and also raises 10 pigs and 300 chickens. Her husband is a construction worker. They have a monthly income of about 3,000.000 Vietnam dong (VND). 

She has participated in SEDA since 2005 and has always used her loans to invest in her livestock. 

In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 7,630,000 VND to buy food for pigs and chickens.

loans.use: to buy food for pigs and chickens

loans.name: Cuc

texts.en:
Cuc T. N. was born in 1969. She lives in Ha Lam 3 village with her husband and two children. 

She grows rice and also raises 10 pigs and 300 chickens. Her husband is a construction worker. They have a monthly income of about 3,500,000 Vietnam dong (VND). 

She has participated in SEDA since 2005 and has always used her loans to invest in her livestock. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 5,0140,000 VND to buy food for her pigs and chickens.

loans.use: to buy food for her pigs and chickens

loans.name: Anwer Sultana's Group

texts.en:
Anwer Sultana has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her husband’s business of selling vegetables and fruits. With the loan, he will buy fresh seasonal fruits and vegetables to sell.
 
Anwer lives in Faisalabad, which is an industrial city in Pakistan famous for its textile industry. She has been living there in a two-room brick house in the area of Medina Town for the past 14 years with her family. 

She is very supportive lady. In order to support her family financially, she works as a women's health worker in her community. She gives health awareness among the ladies of her region. It earns her reasonable income every month. 

She also is a very good mother and a housewife who does well taking care of her family.She has a 15-year-old son who is studying in the 10th grade. 

She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application to Asasah. She hopes that it will help her husband to improve his business and increase his monthly profits. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with her hand raised is Anwer Sultana

loans.use: to buy seasonal fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene B. is from the town of District 1, Benito Soliven, Isabela. She is 36 years old. Arlene is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Arlene owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Arlene has been engaged in her business for more than a year and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Arlene joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arlene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Arlene is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale . This loan will be the second loan taken out by Arlene from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Dewi Fortuna Group

texts.en:
Jero Pudak S. is the leader of the "Dewi Fortuna" Group. Currently, Jero Pudak S. is requesting her second loan. The loan will be used to buy four pigs, whereas feed will be purchased from the profits gained from the sales of the first loan period.

Jero Pudak S. is very excited to pursue this business because it is proven to help the family income. Her husband is very supportive of this and often helps her in the care of their pigs.

Jero Pudak S. has a dream to use profits from all the work raising these pigs to renovate her house and buy a cabinet for her son.

loans.use: To buy four pigs.

loans.name: The

texts.en:
The T. Phan is 47 years old with one child, who attends high school.  

Being a farmer, her main activities are growing rice and vegetables and raising chickens.  Since a divorce in 2008, she has had to work more in order to provide a good education for her child. 

She has increased the numbers of paddies to grow more kinds of vegetables so she can earn a stable income to support her famiy. Participating in our credit program since 2009, she has been a good re-payer and used loans effectively to develop her farming. 

Currently, she wants a loan of 4,142,000 VND to buy food and fertilizer for chickens and rice.

loans.use: to buy food and fertilizer for chickens and rice.

loans.name: Hang

texts.en:
Hang T. N. is 33 years old with one child, who attends high school.  Being a farmer, her main activities are growing rice and vegetables and raising chickens.  

After a divorce in 2008, she has had to work more in order to provide a good education for her child. She has increased the numbers of paddies to grow more kinds of vegetables so she can earn a stable income to support her family. 

Participating in our credit program since 2009, she has been a good re-payer and used loans effectively to develop her farming. Currently, she wants a loan of 5,014,000 VND to buy food and fertilizer for chickens and rice.

loans.use: to buy  food and fertilizer for chickens and rice.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda A. is from the village of Namnama, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 56 years old. Luzviminda is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Luzviminda owns and operates a clothing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling second-hand clothing to the local community. Luzviminda has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Luzviminda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luzviminda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional clothes to sell. Luzviminda is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional clothes to sell. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Luzviminda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional clothes to sell

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan P., aged 62, is from Phnom Penh city, Cambodia. She is an elderly woman who is the mother of nine children, six of whom are married and live independently, while the other three are single and work in a variety of jobs. Chan P. says that most of her income comes from her three children because she and her husband stay at home without earning any money; they just manage household duties for the whole family. Chan P. has decided to seek a loan on Kiva to buy a window and door in order to replace broken ones.

loans.use: to buy a window and door in order to replace broken ones

loans.name: Mamlakat

texts.ru: Халимова Мамлакат проживает в районе Рудаки. Ей 71 год. Она замужем, имеет 5 детей. Ее дети уже взрослые и живут отдельно. Она сама занимается животноводством. Разводит крупнорогатый скот у себя дома. В этом ей помогает её муж. Она разводит скот в дальнейшем для продажи. Этим видом деятельности Мамлакат занимается 28 лет. Она берет кредит для закупа крупнорогатого скота.
texts.en: Mamlakat H. lives in the Rudaki region. She is 71 years old. She is married and has five children. Her children have already grown up and live separately. She is doing animal husbandry and breeds large horned cattle at home. Her husband is helping her. She is breeding the cattle for resale in the future. Mamlakat has been in this business for 28 years. She is taking out the loan to buy large horned cattle.

loans.use: to buy large horned cattle

loans.name: Som

texts.en: Som T. is a 40-year-old mother of two teenage children. She is a seamstress who lives in Phnom Penh. Her husband, Say Chea, aged 40, repairs sewing machines at the same factory. In addition to these jobs, they are also local farmers who grow rice crops and some fruit on their own farmland. Presently, Som T. and her husband face difficulties with traveling. They walk to work or go by taxi because they have no vehicle for commuting purposes. To solve this problem, Som T. is requesting a loan to buy a new motorcycle to use to commute to work.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle to use to commute to work

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra belongs to Faisalabad which is located in Punjab, Pakistan and known for its textile industry. She has been living there in the area of Madina town with her family in a 2-room brick house for the past 10 years. 

She is married to N. M. who is 38 years old and operates a billiard shop in the market where young children come to play billards and pay a fee. He has been in this business for the past three years and in this number of years, he has become renowned for his business.  
   
Azra is a very supportive lady by nature. She works as a lady health worker in her community. She gives health awareness talks among the ladies of her region. It earns her a reasonable income every month. She is the mother of two children. Both of them are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy another billiard table to provide more playing opportunities to his customers. 

Azra is hopeful that an investment will be productive one for him. She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application through Asasah.

loans.use: To buy another billiard table for billiard shop.

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem L. S., 43, is a widow and the mother of two teenage children. One of her children is a worker in a construction shop, and the other is attending school. Sem L. S. has been in the business of farming for a long time. She lives in the province of Kompong Cham. She owns and operates a rice farm, from which she earns a daily income. Currently, her living conditions are not comfortable because her old ladder has been broken from so much use. She wants to buy a new ladder, but she doesn’t have enough money to do so. Sem L. S. is going to use her loan to buy a new ladder to replace the damaged one.

loans.use: To buy a new ladder

loans.name: Bach

texts.en: Bach T. N. is 54 years old. She is living with her family in Uy No commune. Being a tailor, she focuses on making traditional dress.   There are a lot of kinds of designs in her shop so she is always busy with orders from customers. Every month, she can get 4,500,000 VND per month. Therefore, her family’ living conditions are greatly improved.  Joining our program in 2004, she has invested effectively in her tailor shop. This new loan cycle, she wants to have a loan of 8,938,000 to buy more cloth.

loans.use: to buy more cloth.

loans.name: Islomidin

texts.ru: Рахматов Исломидин проживает в районе Рудаки. Возраст, 47 лет. Женат. Имеет 5 детей. Сын, на заработках за границей. Сам Исломидин имеет средне - специальное образование, технолог. Он уже 28 лет преподает в средней школе. Кроме того он занимается животноводством. Разводит крупнорогатый скот в дальнейшем для продажи. В этой области уже 8 лет. Кредит берет для покупки бычков.
texts.en: Islomidin R. lives in the Rudaki region. He is 47 years old. He is married and has five children. His son is working abroad. Islomidin has specialized secondary education, he is a technician. He has been teaching in the secondary school for 28 years. He also does animal husbandry. He breeds large horned cattle for future resale and has been in this business for eight years. He is taking out the loan to buy calves.

loans.use: to buy calves

loans.name: Anh's Group

texts.en:
Anh  K. T. N.,  28 years old with one child, is living in Co Loa commune. Being a tailor, she has opened a small design fashion shop in her village and she is always busy in this shop with a lot of orders from customers.  Running it for 4 years since she received her first loan in 2008, now her shop is bigger and creates more profit. Currently, she wants to have a loan of 5,014,000 VND to buy  cloth.

 Khanh T. N. is 42 years old with two children. She has shop that provides motorbike repair service. She needs to have a loan of 5,014,000 VND to  buy more  motor bike parts.

 Ky T. N. is 55 years old with three children. She has a small shop that sells fruit in Co Loa market. She wants to have a loan of 5,014,000 VND to invest in her shop.

 Quyen  L. T. C. is 35 years old with two children. She is raising 200 chickens for eggs. She wants to have a loan of 5,014,000 VND to buy feed for them.

loans.use: to buy  cloth to make clothing.

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem belongs to an industrial city of Pakistan called Gujranwala. It is located in Punjab, Pakistan. She has been living there in the area of Kalar Abadi in a 3-room brick house with her family for the past five years. Her husband has a business selling vegetables. His shop is located in a nearby market where he has attracted a good customer base and offers them fresh vegetables. 

Naseem is a very supportive lady by nature. She does sewing work for her community members. She learnt this art from her mother and is now taking advantage of her skills to earn money for her family. She has given birth to three children. Her eldest son is studying while others are not of school-going age yet. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who will utilize the loan in buying fresh seasonal vegetables to sell in his shop. He has been operating this business for the past five years and Naseem is confident that after this investment, his income will increase and her family will be able to enjoy better financial conditions.
 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit record by paying her installments on time and by attending every recovery meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Naseem.

loans.use: To buy seasonal vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Inoyatullo

texts.ru: Нозилов Иноятулло проживает в районе Рудаки. Возраст, 34 года. Женат. Имеет 3 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Иноятулло зарабатывает путём разведения крупнорогатого скота. Он разводит скот у себя дома. Этим видом деятельности занимается более 5 лет. Кредит берет для закупа крупнорогатого скота.
texts.en: Inoyatullo N. lives in the Rudaki region. He is 34 years old, married and has three children. His wife is a homemaker. Inoyatullo makes a living by breeding cattle. He does this at home. He has been in this business for more than five years. He is taking out the loan to buy large horned cattle.

loans.use: to buy large horned cattle

loans.name: Chares

texts.en:
Chares V. is from the village of Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 37 years old. Chares is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Chares owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling green bananas & coconuts for copra in the local community. Chares has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Chares joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Chares has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Chares is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional bananas & coconuts to sell. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Chares from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional bananas & coconuts to sell.

loans.name: Remelinda

texts.en:
Remelinda T. is from the village of Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 59 years old. Remelinda is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Remelinda owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling green bananas in the local community. Remelinda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Remelinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remelinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Remelinda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional bananas & coconuts to sell. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Remelinda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional bananas & coconuts to sell.

loans.name: Mickel

texts.en:
Mickel N. is from the village of San Isidro, Medina, Misamis Oriental. He is 33 years old. Mickel is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Mickel owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising chickens for sale. Mickel has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Mickel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mickel is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Mickel from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth J. is from the village of Plaridel, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 49 years old. Elizabeth is separated from her spouse and has nine school-aged children. To make a living, Elizabeth owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling dried fish, bananas & coconuts for copra in the local community. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Elizabeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional green and yellow bananas to sell. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Elizabeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional green and yellow bananas to sell.

loans.name: Adolf

texts.en: Adolf is 40 years old.  He lives in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda.  He hopes to be able to educate his children up to university.  He is a doctor who runs his own clinic which supplements his monthly salary. He has challenges in purchasing drugs due to limited funds and his dream is to own a pharmacy. Adolf is requesting a loan to purchase drugs to sell.

loans.use: To purchase drugs to sell

loans.name: Tahira Jabeen's Group

texts.en:
Tahira Jabeen A. A. is married and has five children, three of whom attend school.  She does sewing work to financially support her husband. She is very good at her work and receives regular orders from her neighborhood clients. The income she earns from her business helps to pay the utility bills. She lives in an industrial city of Pakistan called Gujranwala, which is located in Punjab province and known for its agriculture. She has been living there in a three-room brick house with her family for the past 15 years. 

Her husband’s name is A. A. and he is a rickshaw driver. With his rickshaw, he provides transport services to his passengers and to school children. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who will utilize the loan to repair his rickshaw engine. With a fully repaired rickshaw, he will be able to provide improved transport services to the passengers and earn better profits. Tahira is hopeful than an investment will help him save his business asset and improve his business condition. She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application to Asasah. 

Note: In the photo, the woman with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Tahira Jabeen A. A.

loans.use: To repair a rickshaw

loans.name: Rosanna

texts.en: Rosanna Z. is from the village of Plaridel, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 34 years old and is married with three school-aged children. To make a living Rosanna owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The shop's main source of income comes primarily from selling daily-use products, such as canned goods, convenience foods, biscuits and beverages, in the local community. Rosanna has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2008 Rosanna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rosanna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. Rosanna is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods and convenience foods to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Rosanna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from this investment to improve and expand the business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods and junk foods to sell

loans.name: Tausi

texts.en:
Tausi is a twenty four year old, enterprising single mother living in her own house in Fort Portal Uganda.

Tausi's dream is to build a permanent house, as she is currently in a semi-permanent accommodation. For three years Tausi has been operating her own beauty salon. She started as an employee but now has her own business and her ambition is to turn it into a beauty parlour of great renown.

One of the challenges she faces is that she has a limited number of driers to serve her increasing number of customers. Tausi intends to use this loan to buy hair driers and cosmetics.

loans.use: to purchase hair driers and cosmetics

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en: Rowena G. is from the village of San Juan, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 59 years old and is married with five adult children. Rowena makes a living from running her own sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The shop's main source of income comes from buying and selling daily-use products, such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, convenience foods and biscuits, in the local community. Rowena has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010 Rowena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rowena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. Rowena is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional beverages and biscuits to sell. This loan will be the second taken out by Rowena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from this investment to improve and expand the business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional beverages & biscuits to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more beers, sodas, and wine for resale.

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred B. is 30 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  He is married and has one child.  His child is currently in school.  Fred has a small retail shop, which he has had for three years.         

To help expand his business, Fred has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more rice and beans for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Fred hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Fred hopes to expand his business and to see himself prosper in life.

loans.use: to purchase more rice and beans for resale.

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en:
Reynaldo S. is from the village of San Juan, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. He is 50 years old. Reynaldo is married and has 6 adult children. He butchers and sells meat (mostly pork) in the market. Reynaldo has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2010, Reynaldo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Reynaldo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Reynaldo is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional pigs to be butchered. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Reynaldo from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional pigs to be butchered

loans.name: Samina Maryam's Group

texts.en:
Samina maryam is a very supportive lady. She operates a decorative embroidery business to financially support her family. She receives orders from different members of her community and fulfills them on time to earn for her family. 

Her husband also involved in the same embroidery business. He operates his shop in the market and provides machine as well as hand embroidery services to his customers. He is very well known among his clients for his good quality work and receives regular orders every month. 

Samina has 2 sons. Both are still too young for school. Samina wants to enroll her eldest son in school in the near future and for that purpose she saves profits every month from her work. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who will buy embroidering material such as beads, colored thread and sketches in bulk quantity to offer better quality services to his clients. 

Samina is hopeful that an investment will help her husband to further improve his business and increase his monthly profits.

She lives with her family in the area of Kalar abadi which is a small residential area in Gujranwala. Gujranwala is a midsized city of Pakistan and known for its industrial importance.

Note: “In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Samina Maryam”.

loans.use: to buy embroidery material for embroidery business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a motorcycle which will be used by her daughter to ride to her work place.

loans.name: Larry

texts.en:
Larry C. is from the village of San Nicolas, Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. He is 54 years old. Larry is single. He buys and sells bananas & coconuts in the local community. Larry has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2007, Larry joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Larry has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Larry is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional coconuts & bananas to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Larry from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional coconuts & bananas to sell

loans.name: Noreen

texts.en:
Noreen N. is 28 years old and lives in the town of Kititale in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has two children.  Neither of her children is currently in school.  Noreen has a small poultry farm, which she has had for three years.         

To help expand her business, Noreen has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more poultry feed for the chickens.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Noreen hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Noreen hopes to expand her business into a big firm with both layers and broilers.

loans.use: to purchase more poultry feed for the chickens.

loans.name: Hannie

texts.en: Hannie is a married woman who lives in Narra, Palawan. She earns her living by selling rice (palay). Her husband Segundino, who is 35 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have two children who are 6 and 8 years old. Hannie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past seven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Hannie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her eighth loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 to purchase rice so that she can continue to save up for future expansion of her business. Hannie is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase rice to sell

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en:
Benedicta S. is from the village of Linabu, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 55 years old. Benedicta is married and has 4 adult children. She has a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk foods & instant noodles in the local community. Benedicta has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2009, Benedicta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Benedicta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Benedicta is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods & junk food to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Benedicta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods & junk food to sell

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice K. is forty-eight years old, married, and has two children aged twenty three and fifteen. Her business is located at a busy area near a college known as Eregi in Kakamega. Kakamega is a rich agricultural land with sugarcane growing as the main farming activity. The region is in the western part of Kenya and is well known as the sugarbelt region. 

Beatrice sells fruits, vegetables, maize, beans and others to local people. She has been in this business for fifteen years now. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is financial constraints. However she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy fruits and vegetables to grow her business and meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to be a wholesaler in the future and open a general store in the same area. She describes herself as focused, eversmiling and reserved.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Ruhorobero Twimukye Group-Ntungamo

texts.en:
35 year-old Osbert M. is affiliated with Ruhorobero Twimukye Group-Ntungamo. It is now 15 years since he began his food sales business in Ruhorobero Trading center food market. For the most part, he has been selling beans, coffee and millet. These are high-value cash crops at the markets in his district and other areas of Western Uganda.  Most of the crops Osbert sells are harvested from his farming gardens. 
Osbert is happily married with 6 kids, and he says this business generates him shillings 100,000 monthly. He is requesting for this loan to expand his food sales business to other areas in Western Uganda.

loans.use: The expansion of his food sales business to other areas in western Uganda

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites E. is from the village of Lagonglong, Misamis Oriental. She is 46 years old. Marites is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Marites owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) shop selling children's products, such as toys & games.   Marites has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marites joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional children's toys. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Marites from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional children's toys

loans.name: Yam

texts.en: Yam T. is 27 years old and her husband, Heng Sroun, is 26. They are from Kompong Tom province. They work from home making furniture which they also sell. Most of their output consists of beds and cupboards, which they accumulate and sell as sets. They also order baskets from the other villagers and sell them to make additional income. Their furniture is made mostly from wood and rattan. The couple has one child who is in school. In order to increase her income, Yam T. has applied for a loan to buy additional beds for resale.

loans.use: To buy additional beds for resale

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence needs a loan to pay school fees.  She is a forty-seven year-old, ambitious lady with four children, living in Fort Portal, Uganda.  She operates a retail shop and has been in business for three years, amidst the challenges of price fluctuations and high rent costs.  Inspite of these challengers, she wishes to become a wholesaler.

loans.use: Pay school fees

loans.name: Lorna

Lorna A. is from the village of Kabulawan, Lagonglong, Misamis Oriental. She is 48 years old. Lorna is married and has 5 adult children.  Lorna owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) shop, selling products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, biscuits & beverages in the local community. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lorna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional biscuits & detergents to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Lorna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Pregreno

texts.en:
Pregreno G., J.. is from the village of San Francisco, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. He is 38 years old.  Pregreno is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Pregreno owns & operates a business selling seafood products, like milkfish and sardines, in the local community.  Pregreno has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Pregreno joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pregreno is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish, like salmon & mackerel. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Pregreno from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

loans.name: Monic

texts.en:
Monic B. is 46 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has four children.  One of her children is currently in school.  Monic has a small retail shop, which she has had for five years.  She also has a second business: a restaurant.  

To help expand her businesses, Monic has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more sugar and soap for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Monic hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her child.  In the future, Monic hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more sugar and soap for resale.

loans.name: Ochirpurev

texts.en: Ochirpurev B. is 32 years old, married, and has two children, one of whom attends school.  They live in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Ochirpurev is a taxi driver and his wife is a beautician. Since 2006 Ochirpurev has been running a taxi business, which is the family’s only source of income at the moment. Ochirpurev owns a plot of land and a small wooden house on it. The house needs some refurbishment.  When winter is over, Ochirpurev wants to do some renovation to the house. He is requesting a loan to purchase cement, wood planks, paints, and wallpaper.

loans.use: To purchase building materials to renovate the family house

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.en:
Esmeralda S., from the village of Alicomohan, Sugbongcogon, Misamis Oriental, is 42 years old, separated from her spouse, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Esmeralda owns and operates a specialized retail store selling coconuts for copras in the local community. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 9000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Esmeralda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, she is requesting her third loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional coconuts for copras to sell. Esmeralda plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About HSPFI:.

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Dewile

texts.en: Dewile is a thirty-six year old hardworking man living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He trades in business and in the four years he has been able to pay school fees for six of his children with the help of his wife, who is a farmer. He has the challenge of seasonal changes that affect coffee prices and his dream is to set up a store. Dewile intends to use the loan to buy coffee.

loans.use: to buy coffee.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is an ambitious married woman living in her own permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. She longs to educate her children to attain a degree as a minimum qualification. For thirty years she has been farming and reaping tangible benefits, despite the changes in the weather pattern. Grace needs the loan to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to pay school fees.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine N. is from the village of Namnama, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 48 years old. Josephine is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Josephine operates a family member's business venture in the services sector, operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing a motorcycle transport business to local community members. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Josephine joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Josephine from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy rice, toothpaste and salt to sell.

loans.name: Mealii

texts.en:
Mealii J. M. is a 41-year-old woman. She is married to Ali Mohamed and they have been blessed with four children. Mealii is a landlady in Miritini, Mombasa and has been in this business for the last eight years. Her business has been a success.

This marks her third loan from KADET, and she plans to renovate her rental houses. She anticipates some profits which she plans to redirect into the construction of more residential houses on her land. Her future dream is to become a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: To renovate her rental houses

loans.name: Morena

texts.en:
Morena L. is from the village of Namnama Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 44 years old. Morena is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Morena owns & operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. Morena has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when she sells one of her raised pigs.

In 2008, Morena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Morena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Morena is requesting a new loan of 30000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Morena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.
